title: what today pollen count uk level london
story: But just how bad is it for people with hay fever  Here is todays pollen count and how you can protect yourself.Heres the pollen forecast for dferent regions of the UK as of Wednesday, July, , .In London, levels have dropped down to moderate, from high earlier this week.Similarly, counts in Bristol, Norwich, Birmingham and most of England are moderate, including Manchester and Liverpool.Wales has also been seeing moderate pollen count today.However, Newcastle and Edinburgh are experiencing higher levels today with both the north east of England and an area including Dumfries, Galloway, Lothian and the Borders seeing a rise in the pollen count.The counts in the rest of Scotland and Northern Ireland are moderate today.Pollen levels are expected to stay broadly similar through Friday, with the count dropping for people in Newcastle and Edinburgh.However, by Friday an area encompassing the south of the country will be experiencing high levels of pollen, including Devon, Cornwall, London and east Anglia.The count in the rest of England will remain moderate, while Belftast, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Aberdeen will experience a low pollen count on Friday.To try and combat the effects of hay fever, you can try a number of things:In times of high pollen, do not cut grass or walk in grassy areas, do not keep fresh flowers in your home, smoke or dry clothes outside as they can catch pollen.There are two ways which might be useful for hay fever sufferers to track periods of high pollen.The Met Office issues a five day pollen forecast which monitors the pollen count across the UK which you can find here.Tech-savvy hay fever sufferers can also download the Hay Fever Relief app which can alert you to the daily pollen count updates as well as give you an expert treatment plan and allow you to track your symptoms.A pollen count is generated by measuring the number of pollen grains in a given volume of air, using a pollen trap.A count of  pollen grains or less is considered low, and a count of , pollen grains or more is considered high.Pollen counts tend to be higher in early morning and late evening, although they can sometimes be high all day long.If the grass is damp, the pollen peak will be later in the morning because the water evaporates before the pollen is released.Pollen rises in the air during the day and then descends at night, as the air cools.In rural areas, the evening peak tends to occur between pm and pm but in the city, where the air stays warmer for longer, the pollen descends later and levels tend to peak between pm and midnight or even later, which is why you may wake up sneezing in the night.Sunny days favour higher pollen counts and rain tends to wash the pollen away, whereas on a cloudy day, pollen builds up only to be released on the next sunny day.

title: pubs can show football but quietly

story: Sol Bamba, , lost his Range Rover, Louis Vuitton bag and a Cartier watch when his family home was targeted by three burglars last year.A court heard the trio struck while Bambas team, Cardf City, were playing in Nice, France - and his we Chloe was away with their three children aged five to .But the Ivory Coast international - who has also played for Leeds and Leicester - came home to find their house ransacked.CCTV images from his home showed the three thieves wearing dark clothes, gloves and hoodies as they walked across his lawn into the house.Daniel Flynn, , was seen driving his Range Rover Sport away from the house after the property was plundered.Cardf Crown Court heard other private possessions were smashed leaving we Chloe devastated at the intrusion into her home.Judge Richard Twomlow said: I am told the house was ransacked and property smashed during the burglary.The exclusive Louis Vuitton bag and a Cartier watch were among her possessions taken in the raid - and left the family feeling violated.Cardf City were playing a pre-season friendly against OGC Nice on the day of the burglary. The defender, who speaks five languages, ed home to discover the damage.Flynn pleaded guilty at Cardf Crown Court to burgling Mr Bambas property on the outskirts of the Welsh capital in July last year.Accomplice Kyle Harris, , from Rumney, Cardf, was earlier jailed for two years after admitting his part in the burglary.The prosecution said Flynn had played a willing part and had been involved in many burglaries.Flynn will be sentenced later this month after pre-sentence reports into his background. The third man is still waiting to be brought to justice.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester lockdown cricket match
story: Onlookers cheered as the amateur cricket tournament went ahead in Spinney Hill Park, just metres away from Leicesters new pop up coronavirus test centre. Sundays cricket match, which was posted across social media last night, was also held just yards from the police station.Spectators in groups of more than six stood side by side and were not following two-metre social distancing rules.There were also two men manning a desk topped with ious trophies - in what seemed to be an informal cricket tournament.This comes just one day before Leicester was put into a new lockdown by the government, following a spike in the citys coronavirus cases.Angry locals have taken to social media, outraged that nothing was done about the illegal cricket match.One commented on Facebook: Wow I have no words.Another said: And they wonder why we are on a second lockdown, and this is next to a police station and a COVID testing station.A third commented: And people wonder why its spreading. W******.Leicester was put into the UKs first local lockdown  on Monday night, after a worrying spike saw Public Health England identy , cases — with  in just two weeks.The shocking numbers mean that the city accounts for  per cent of all coronavirus cases in the UK.New local lockdown measures mean pubs and salons will not re-open on July  along with the rest of England.It also means that outside gatherings of six people is now banned, and social distancing must still be observed.Non-essential shops and schools will also be told to close, effectively placing Leicester back to where the rest of the UK was in May. And Mr Hancock today announced that in some cases police would enforce the lockdown.He said: We will bring forward a legal change very shortly, in the next couple of days.Because some of the measures that weve had to take in Leicester will require a legal underpinning.Despite claims that police were not present at Spinney Hill on Sunday, cops confirmed that they were called and did move people on.A spokesperson from Leicestershire Police said: We are aware of a video of a cricket match taking place on Spinney Hill Park which has been posted on social media.After receiving a report on Sundayofficers attended the scene to move people on.Routine patrols have been increased in the area as a result of community reports.We will continue to provide proportionate policing under the relevant legislation to help keep people safe.Our approach has always been clear that we will use the four E’s – Engage, Explain, Encourage and Enforce where necessary.Communities are encouraged to follow the Government’s guidelines.Leicester City Council did not respond when The Sun Online asked for a comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Prof Swinson, , won the partyaposs leadership race last July and claimed she could become Prime Minister.She hoped to scoop up pro-EU supporters, sweep to No and torpedo Brexit. However, when voters went to the polls at Decemberaposs general election, her partyaposs  MPs were cut to just  and she lost her East Dunbartonshire seat.It was the second time she had been dumped by electors in four years, after losing the constituency in  before regaining it in . Working from home became the norm, socialising was forced online and missing loved ones became an everyday occurance. As the virusapos hold begins to ease, some places are beginning to see the strict restrictions lted, but weaposre still a long way from le as we knew it. Non-essential businesses - including pubs - will reopen their doors in England this weekend, and people will finally be able to reunite with family for longer periods of time. But whataposs next  Back in May, Prime Minister Boris Johnson revealed his -page road map plan for getting the UK out of lockdown, both socially and economically. The next big change is due to happen this weekend, with a large number of restrictions being relaxed in England. Pubs, hairdressers, hotels, campsites, restaurants, cinemas, museums and galleries can reopen their doors on Saturday  July and two households will also be able to meet indoors and even stay overnight - as long as they maintain social distancing. There are another  other cities or towns which are deemed at risk and could follow in Leicesteraposs footsteps. And then what  While many things are starting to get back to normal, many businesses and industries are still waiting for the green light to reopen. Nightclubs, bowling alleys, indoor playareas, swimming pools, tattoo studios, water parks and conference centres are just some of the places weaposre still waiting for an update for.  The beauty industry is still at a standstill, with everything except hairdressers - including beauty salons and nail bars - remaining closed. However there may be a light at the end of the tunnel for the fitness industry, including gyms. Despite Government sources says gyms remain shut because there is a “far greater risk of infection” due to people breathing harder and touching surfaces, they could be open in a fortnight. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden has: Subject to public health, our aspiration is to reopen gyms  leisure facilities in mid-July. The government wants all children to go back to school in September, and parents will face finesthey donapost sent their kids in. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe future of a key health body was thrown into doubt today after No refused to rule out scrapping or reforming it - as soon as this winter. Downing Street refused to guarantee Public Health England would continue in its current form after Tory MPs called for it to be scrapped.It comes after Boris Johnson yesterday said some parts of the state had been sluggish in responding to the coronavirus pandemic. He did not say which bits he meant.Public Health England has been responsible for much of the controversial testing programme in England, which saw widespread community testing axed in March. It was then slowly brought back as capacity increased. Briefing against PHE intensied overnight as a former minister told the Dailyit appeared destined for the chop. Iain Duncan Smith, the former Tory leader, added to the newspaper: I would abolish PHE tomorrow. What this has shown is thatministers are to take responsibility for things they must also have control, and they donapost have control over PHE. The newspaper reported that the Treasury was reviewing whether plans to establish a new PHE headquarters in Harlow, Essex, should go ahead. Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman today insisted PHE was playing a key role but did not rule out whether it could undergo major reforms or be scrapped. He said: “PHE are playing a key role in our response working on important issues such as detection, surveillance, contact-tracing and testing. “They have been working hard to help protect the country and to provide insight in our efforts to beat the virus. “Separately, you’re aware that the roadmap we published in May says we must learn the right lessons from this crisis and act to ensure the government’s structures are fit to cope.

Officials have until December  to secure a trade pact, with Britain due to leave the EU single market and customs union in less than six months. Mrs Merkel warned the German parliament the bloc must and should prepare for a situation in which an agreement does not happen.  She added: “The progress made during the negotiations have been, to put it mildly, minimal. “With Great Britain, we have agreed to speed up these negotiations to be able to agree on a deal in autumn, which would then also need to be ratied until the end of the year. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: “It was never our intention to extend the transition period. “We want to continue to work constructively with the EU and we believe that there is a free trade agreement to be reached. “But we have also been very clear that we will be prepared for either eventuality at the end of the year, whether that be an FTAor a trading relationship based on the same terms Australia currently has.” While Britain formally left the bloc on January , exit triggered a transition to allow time to agree a trade deal.  Talks are continuing in Brussels between the teams led by the Prime Ministeraposs Europe adviser David Frost and the EUaposs chief negotiator Michel Barnier. Anti-Brexit campaigners intensied their warnings over failing to strike a trade agreement. Best for Britain chief executive Naomi Smith said: “The German Chancellor’s statement highlights two deeply worrying patterns. “The first is the continued lack of progress, despite the Government refusing to extend the transition period. “It is clear from all the available data that a failure to secure a comprehensive trade deal with the EU by the end of the year would amount to throwing what limited economic recovery we see in the second half of  down the drain.

story: NewsTories miss coronavirus target to get , laptops to needy pupilsSome , of the devices were sent to school pupils after they went months without IT at home - but it falls short of previous pledges and many were only sent in the last weekShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsThe government has been sending out laptops to the pupils most in need", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Gavin Williamson had claimed , laptops and tablets were on schedule to be distributed by June . But the Education Secretaryaposs pledge fell short - as official figures show , were delivered or dispatched by that date. Despite schools shutting three months ago, almost a quarter of the laptops or tablets - , - were only distributed in the last week. And even then, pupils may still be waiting for tens of thousands of the devices. Official figures only record when laptops are dispatched to councils or schools - not when they are received or given to a child. The statistics also include laptops that are still in transit awaiting delivery. Shadow Education Secretary Kate Green branded the figures extremely disappointing. She said: Disadvantaged children have now spent nearly a term without adequate access to education. Ministers need to get the remaining laptops to the families who need them immediately, and provide proper support for children who will be catching up over the summer.” The government pledged to send laptops to the most vulnerable and most disadvantaged children without access to IT at home.  Care leavers and children with social workers were first in line, followed by disadvantaged pupils in Year . The government sad the £million scheme would hand laptops to schools permanently to improve kidsapos education. But unions have said even the ambition to send out , of the machines is not enough. The ASCL union has described the availability of laptops as a national scandal, warning they cover a tiny proportion of pupils without access to technology and we need to do better. Gavin Williamson said on June  he was aiming to distribute , laptops by the end of the month. He told MPs: We are on schedule to receive all those laptops and get them distributed by the end of the month.

story: NewsUK insists it has enough remdesivir after Trump buys up global supplies of Covid- drugThe US has sparked anger by buying nearly all the stock for the next three months - but the UK insisted it had secured supplies of the anti-viral pillShareCommentsByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  JUL NewsDonald Trump snapped up virtually all supplies of the drug for three months ", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has enough stocks of the drug remdesivir after the US sparked anger, buying nearly all the stock for the next three months.The Department of Health today confirmed it had secured supplies of the anti-viral pill that can speed the recovery of patients infected with the coronavirus.Officials assured people they had bought enough of the drug in advance to treat every NHS patient who needs it. Health Secretary Matt Hancock hailed remdesivir the “biggest step forward” in treating Covid- when it was approved for use on the NHS in May. The reassurance comes after the US Department of Health, and Human Servicessaid it had secured more than , treatment courses of remdesivir for American hospitals. This represents  per cent of the US pharmaceutical firm Gilead’s projected production for July,  per cent of production in August and  per cent of production in September, alongside an allocation for clinical trials. The US sparked anger after brokering the deal while also gloating about the purchase. America’s Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar said in a statement: “President Trump has struck an amazing deal to ensure Americans have access to the first authorised therapeutic for Covid-.”  But Oxford University’s Professor Peter Horby, who led trials when the drug was first developed, said: “It does raise two very important questions: what is a fair price for a drug and what is fair access to a drug, and those are common issues but are particularly important in a global crisis like this. “That’s part of the fair access question, the trial that gave the result that allowed remdesivir to sell their drug wasn’t just done in the US, there were patients participating through other European countries, in the UK as well, and internationally, Mexico and other places. “And I wonder how they would feel knowing now that the drug is going to have restricted availability in their own country and would they have volunteered for that trialthey had known that ” Remdesivir is an anti-viral drug that was developed for use against Ebola.

story: NewsFirst picture of five-year-old girl found stabbed to death next to her mumA murder investigation has been launched after Sayagi Sivanantha died in hospital - the five-year-old had been found fatally stabbed in Mitcham, south LondonShareByLorraine King:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsSayagi Sivanantha died in hospital ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis is the first picture of a five-year-old girl found stabbed to death next to a woman lying in a pool of blood. Met Police have launched a murder investigation after Sayagi Sivanantha died in hospital and her mum Sutha Karunanantham, , is in hospital with le-threatening injuries. In a statement, police said: Detectives have launched a murder investigation following the death of a five-year-old girl in Mitcham. While formal identication has not yet taken place, investigating officers are confident the victim is Sayagi Sivanantham. Neighbour Elsa Gonzales, , found the pair inside a flat in Monarch Parade in Mitcham, south London, on Tuesday afternoon. She described hearing screaming and crying coming from the flat next door, where the family-of-four from Sri Lanka lived. I saw the woman lying on the floor in a pool of blood, she told the PA news agency. There was blood everywhere. I looked on the bed and saw the girl, she was covered in a blanket. Police said no arrests have been made and they are not looking for anyone  in connection with the incident.  Detective Chief Inspector Justin Howick said: “This is a tragic incident and we are working very hard to fully understand what has happened. Whilst I know the effects of this incident will, understandably, shock and sadden the local community, please be reassured that we are not seeking anyone  in connection with Sayagi’s death and there is no cause for the community to be fearful or alarmed.“I would like to hear from anyone who feels they may have information that could assist our investigation.” Mrs Gonzales, who has lived at Monarch Parade for  years, said: Itaposs really breaking my heart, the child was a smart kid, she was always smiling. She was a cheeky little girl, always playing with the neighbourhood kids. To see her so leless, itaposs like my heart is bleeding. Shewas a good mum.  Superintendent Richard Smith, from the Met’s South West Command Unit, said: “Today a family are grieving for their little girl, and we are doing everything we can to support them.This terrible incident has left a family distraught and the local community in shock.I would like to pay tribute to the police officers and ambulance service colleagues who responded to this frightening situation and thank them for working so hard to try and save Sayagi.

title: homesick student cycles 2000 miles
story: NewsHomesick student cycles , miles from Aberdeen to Athens to see his family in lockdownCleon Papadimitriou, , set out on May  and cycled for  days from Aberdeen, where he is studying electronic engineering, to Melissia, near Athens, surviving on bread, peanut butter and sardinesShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsCleon Papadimitriou cycled , miles in  days", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA homesick student beat the lockdown by cycling , miles from Britain to visit his family in Greece in  days. Cleon Papadimitriou, , got on his bike after getting fed up of waiting for travel restrictions to be lted. He left his student flat in Aberdeen on May  and took a ferry to Holland before cycling through Germany, Austria and Italy carrying a load of  kilograms. From there he took another ferry to Patras in Greece, arriving in Athens seven weeks after setting off. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. Cleon said: I like adventures so when I couldnapost fly home I decided to go by bike. I had a lot of punctures and had to put up with snow, hail and intense heat along the way. Sometimes the bicycle tire burst two or three times a day, and that not only cost me a lot of time but it wasn’t good for my morale either.  It was a lesson I had to learn to manage. Iaposm a bit saddle sore but it was worth it, he added. Cleon camped along his marathon journey and survived on bread, peanut butter and tins of sardines. His parents greeted him when he arrived in Melissia, north of the Greek capital, with a laurel crown and a large banner saying: Welcome Home Cleon: One more challenge accomplished! Cleon plans to fly back to Scotland to complete his electronic engineering degree at Aberdeen University when flights resume. He began studying there in September .

title: hotels reopening rules holidays open
story: Advertorial new rules hotels MUST follow to reopen - plus the amazing work some have been doing during lockdownYoull notice some changes next time you check-in to stay at a hotel after the government announced a raft of guidelinesShareByDave Masters:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Advertorial", url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEverybody is crying out for a holiday after months of lockdown and staycations are set to soar with trips abroad looking unlikely for most. The good news is the government has given permission for hotels with en suite showering facilities, or one designated shower facility per guest room, to reopen. But it has issued strict guidelines for owners to follow in order to keep staff and visitors safe and stop the spread of Covid-. The seven key new rules are designed to help employers, employees and the self-employed in England only understand how to work as safely as possible and protect their customers while keeping to the recommended social distancing guidance applicable at the time. Below are the seven vital changes you will notice next time you stay at a hotel in England...plus we speak to a hotel in Glasgow to see how they have been adapting during the crisis. . Screens in reception  Hotels have been told to take measures to make reception areas safer, with increased cleaning, keeping the activity time as short as possible and where possible the addition of screens between guests and staff. . Lt limits Bosses have been told to consider minimising lt usage from reception, and urged to provide clear signage for new lt rules. . New room service delivery plans Where offering room service, the guidelines state measures such as dropping butler’s trays outside door should be introduced. Hotels are also encouraged to add tips to the bill. . Cleaning checklist for housekeeping  Housekeeping staff must follow government handwashing guidelines, and now make a checklist of all hand contact services to be cleaned when each guests vacates. . Swimming pools and sauna rules Hotels have been told to check the latest government guidance on opening of additional guest facilities . . Face masks for guests  Guests are to be encouraged to wear masks on communal corridors to help minimise the spread of Covid-. . Social distancing at bars Owners must ensure that any bar or dining area is only opened in a way compliant with UK government guidance on the hospitality sector. Hotel supports hospital heroes with meals  When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Laura McKenzie had a flood of cancelled bookings at her Glasgow hotel, Cathedral House. The McKenzie family had spent  months building up business at the boutique hotel, which offers a luxurious “home from home” atmosphere, so they were shattered. But within days Laura, who runs the hotel with husband Shane and two of their children Callum,  and -year-old Anna, was inspired to help out staff at nearby Glasgow Royal Infirmary. First, they block booked rooms for hospital staff at a reduced rate then with the help of a donation from Celtic FC Foundation, set to work making meals for them. “I made a few phone calls and straightaway we had the team we needed to start producing the meals. It was probably ten days from thinking: ‘This is horric, this is the end’ to thinking ‘We can do something good and support the local hospital here.’” Laura knows the pressure that NHS staff are under because her daughter, Emily, , is a junior doctor in Dundee, so she was desperate to help. With the hotel’s staff all on furlough, Laura assembled a team of volunteer chefs from the city. The Red Onion’s patron chef John Quigley was one of the first to volunteer and Laura worked with the head nurse at the Infirmary to set up the menu.  “We decided we were going to do  meals a day,” she says. “We did  veggie options and  meat options and bought little takeaway tubs and labelled them all up with little stickers that said: ‘With love from Cathedral House’. And every night at quarter to seven the driver from the hospital would come and take the big boxes of food away. He said there was always such a buzz. People were like: ‘Oh, the food’s coming! What have we got today ’” The hotel has now delivered more than , dishes such as jambalaya, bangers and mash and Thai curry. “It was a simple menu, all cooked fresh with lots of veggies and the sort of dishes you’d cook for yourself when you get home from work,” says Laura. Doctors staying at the hotel were delighted because Laura would text them to seethey wanted a dinner putting aside – and they could pop down to the kitchen to collect it. Laura’s home-from-home hospitality was a real comfort to her guests.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAlton Towers has given visitors an insight as to how the theme park will look when it reopens on Saturday. The popular tourist attraction will open its doors on July  for the first time in more than three months as lockdown measures ease in England. Pictures taken from inside the park show guests will have a completely dferent experience. Like zoos, anyone wanting to visit Alton Towers will have to pre-book for entry, with the park opening at limited capacity. Queues will be spaced out to ensure people are social distancing, and face masks will be compulsory for anyone over the age of six on certain rides, including Nemesis, Galactica, Oblivion, The Smiler, Wicker Man, Rita, THTEEN and Runaway Mine Train. At the park entrance, temperature checks will be carried out with a non-touch thermometer. Anyone with a temperature over . degrees will be denied entry.The majority of rides and outdoor attractions will reopen, but some indoor facilities will stay shut, BirminghamLive reports.Staff will also wear PPE and rides will be thoroughly cleaned regularly.  Last month, incredible drone footage showed an eerily empty Alton Towers as operators worked on the rides at dizzying heights. Other rollercoasters such as The Smiler sit eerily empty while carriages can be seen going around tracks on other rides - but with no passengers on board. The Alton Towers website reads: In line with the latest Government guidance, we are delighted to confirm that Alton Towers Resort will reopen on the  July . We can’t wait to welcome you back.This follows the successful opening of the Alton Towers Gardens earlier this month, and is in line with the UK Government guidance on the reopening of open-air attractions.  From  July, the rest of the theme park will reopen, including the majority of our rides and outdoor attractions, although some indoor facilities must remain closed for now.  We will reopen with signicantly reduced numbers and a range of hygiene and safety measures to protect you and our employees.All guests must bring a suitable mask with them when they visit our attraction. Only securely fitted face masks should be worn on rides for safety reasons and we would recommend removing face masks on water rides in case they get wet.

In May, France counted  additional deaths every day on average.This decrease has allowed the government to gradually re-open businesses, restaurants and some schools since May .Coronavirus cases in France remain low :KEY EVENTExpert says the UK must “prepare for the worst” this winterThe UK must #xCprepare for the worst#xD this winter, instead of relying on the development of a successful coronavirus vaccine, an expert has said.Sir John Bell, regius professor of medicine at Oxford University, told MPs too many assumptions had already been made during the course of the Covid- pandemic.Instead, he said, it would be advisable to prepare for the colder weather, and flu season, without depending on a breakthrough from researchers working on a vaccine.His comments came in response to Greg Clark, chairman of the Science and Technology Select Committee, who askedthe country should be preparing for the winter without a vaccine, orone might be ready in time.Sir John said: #xCThis whole epidemic has relied too heavily on assumptions that have turned out not to be true.#xCSo, my strong advice is be prepared for the worst.#xDSir John Bell:Number of people who have coronavirus immunity could be higher than antibody tests suggestThe number of people who have coronavirus immunity could be higher than antibody tests suggest, a new study indicates. Research from Karolinska Institutet and Karolinska University Hospital shows that many people with mild or asymptomatic Covid- demonstrate so-called T-cell immunity to the disease.This is eventhey have not tested positive for antibodies to the virus. Marcus Buggert, assistant professor at the Centre for Infectious Medicine, Karolinska Institutet, and one of the paper#xs main authors, said: #xCT-cells are a type of white blood cells that are specialised in recognising virus-infected cells, and are an essential part of the immune system. #xCAdvanced analyses have now enabled us to map in detail the T-cell response during and after a Covid- infection. #xCOur results indicate that roughly twice as many people have developed T-cell immunity compared with those who we can detect antibodies in.#xD" content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _JS.jpg":Public Health Englands future in doubt as No refuses to rule out scrapping itThe future of a key health body was thrown into doubt today after No refused to rule out scrapping or reforming it - as soon as this winter.Downing Street refused to guarantee Public Health England would continue in its current form after Tory MPs called for it to be scrapped.It comes after Boris Johnson yesterday said some parts of the state had been #xCsluggish#xD in responding to the coronavirus pandemic. He did not say which bits he meant.Public Health England has been responsible for much of the controversial testing programme in England, which saw widespread community testing axed in March.It was then slowly brought back as capacity increased.Read the full story here.:More people prioritising space for home officeTwo-fthsof people would prioritise space for a home officethey were searching for a new property, a survey has found. One in sixpeople said they have become more interested in updating their home since the coronavirus lockdown started, the Home Builders Federationfound. Nearly a fthof people want to change the style of their home, according to the research, carried out ahead of New Homes Week Unlocked between July  and , which showcases the benefits of new build homes. Interest in interior design appears to have particularly increased among Millennials, with nearly a quarterof  to -year-olds saying they have become more interested in this during the lockdown, the survey of , people across the UK found.The findings were released as Halax said that in June, mortgage applications from first-time buyers nearly doubled. Halax saw a % increase from May as buyers looked to step on to the housing ladder. Halax said East Anglia, the North West and the North East in England are proving some of the most popular choices for those looking for a new home after lockdown, with mortgage applications already higher in these regions than levels seen before the pandemic.A survey from Halax of more than , people found that over halfof workers who had been working from home now think that there is less need for people to live in a city. Many said that being close to their office is no longer an important factor when purchasing a property.Many Brits are working from their bedrooms:Walkers confirms  members of workforce test positiveLeicester-based crisp-maker Walkers said  members of its ,-strong workforce had tested positive for coronavirus. The figure - equivalent to % of its employees - relates to testing during the course of June. Public health officials are understood to believe that the cases reflect community transmission of coronavirus. It is also understood that workers with confirmed or suspected cases of Covid- are self-isolating at home, while on full pay. :NHS trust blames second, late peak for high death figuresAn NHS trust is blaming a #xCsecond, late peak#xD after its hospitals recorded more than % of weekly Covid- deaths for the whole of England. East Kent Hospitals said it saw high numbers of patients with coronavirus in late May and cited the area#xs elderly demographic. In the week to June ,  people died at hospitals run by the trust after testing positive for the disease, Government figures published on Tuesday show. This was nearly double the NHS trust with the second highest figure, George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust in Warwickshire, which recorded  deaths.East Kent Hospitals NHS Trust :KEY EVENTCoronavirus UK death toll rises by  to , in week-on-week increaseThe total UK coronavirus death toll has risen by  to a total of ,.It is a week-on-week rise compared to last Wednesday.Read the full story here. Experts say more local lockdowns in England can be expected:UK has enough stocks of remdesivir drug after US buys nearly all of itThe UK has enough stocks of the drug remdesivir, the Department of Health has confirmed, after the US bought nearly all the manufacturing stock for the next three months.The Department of Health said it had secured supplies of remdesivir in advance and had enough to treat every NHS patient who needs it.It comes after the US Department of Health and Human Servicessaid it had secured more than , treatment courses of remdesivir for American hospitals.This represents % of the US pharmaceutical firm Gilead#xs projected production for July , % of production in August , and % of production in September , alongside an allocation for clinical trials.Remdesivir is an anti-viral drug that was developed for use against Ebola.It has been approved for use in Covid- patients by the US and the UK, among other countries, after data suggested it can cut recovery time by about four days.However, there is no clinical trial data as yet to suggest it improves survival from coronavirus. :KEY EVENTUK coronavirus hospital death toll up by  in lowest Wednesday rise since lockdownThe UK coronavirus hospital death toll has risen by  to a total of ,.In England  more people died in hospitals from Covid-, in Scotland one more patient died, and six more patients also died in Wales. No new deaths were reported in Northern Ireland.It#xs the lowest rise on Wednesday since the lockdown began.On recent Wednesdays, the hospital death toll increased by  on June ,  on June ,  on June ,  on June ,  on May  and  on May .The biggest rise on a Wednesday was  on April , when the UK was in the deadliest days of its outbreak.A further  people, who tested positive for the Coronavirushave died, bringing the total number of confirmed reported deaths in hospitals in England to ,. Click here for the full story. :KEY EVENTWalkers crisps confirms coronavirus outbreak at Leicester factorySnack giant Walkers has confirmed  positive cases of Covid- at its factory in Leicester.The firm, which employs , people across the site in the Beaumont Leys area of the city, said it had seen a #xCsteady increase#xD in the number of confirmed cases during June.Walkers claimed its track and trace procedure indicated the transmission of the virus was #xCnot in our factory#xD.Instead, it believes the rise #xCcoincides with the roll-out and uptake of testing#xD in Leicester. Click here for the full story. :Six more Covid- deaths confirmed in WalesA further six patients have died after testing positive for coronavirus in Wales, health officials have announced.Scotland earlier announced that two more people had died after being diagnosed with the killer virus.:Boris Johnson snubs calls to give m people a £, coronavirus benefit boostBoris Johnson has snubbed calls to boost benefits for million needy people during the coronavirus crisis.The government agreed to increase Universal Credit and Working Tax Credit by #xA a week for one year to help people cope during the pandemic.But they#xve refused to match the increase for so-called #xlegacy benefits#x - despite the fact these are still claimed by huge numbers who haven#xt moved to six-in-one benefit UC.The vast majority of the roughly million people still on legacy benefits claim Employment Support Allowance , meaning they are chronically sick or disabled.For the full story, click here:Government under fire for allowing pubs to reopen on a SaturdayA police and crime commissioner has criticised the Government#xs decision to reopen bars on a Saturday - and warned of a #xClikely threat of serious disorder#xD. David Jamieson, the elected commissioner for the West Midlands Police area, urged people to act sensibly when pubs finally reopen after lockdown. The Labour commissioner said: #xCI am in favour of the gradual lting of the lockdown, based on the science, but not in the way the Government have proceeded.#xD Warning that Saturday is set to be the busiest day of the year for West Midlands Police, Mr Jamieson added: #xCSignicant preparations are being put in place and we are working closely with pubs to mitigate the threat of disorder. #xCIt would have been sensible for the Government to schedule the first day of pub openings for midweek or the Monday afterwards rather than a Saturday.#xDDavid Jamieson has hit out at the government :Boris Johnson blames problems getting people to understandLeicester was forced into lockdown because of #xCproblems getting people to understand#xD what to do, Boris Johnson claimed today.The Prime Minister said the city had #xCparticular#xD problems that meant a fresh outbreak of the virus was not contained quickly enough.It was not immediately clear what the Prime Minister was referring to.Leicester Labour MP Jon Ashworth has highlighted the city is #xCproudly erse#xD and has high poverty rates - two things that put its citizens more at risk from Covid-.For the full story, click here:One more death in Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon announcesA total of , patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said.Speaking at the Scottish Government#xs coronavirus briefing, the First Minister said eight more people had tested positive for the virus in  hours, taking the total to ,.A total of  patients are in Scottish hospitals with confirmed or suspected Covid-, a fall of  in  hours, she added.Of these,  are intensive care, a drop of two.The death figure announced by the First Minister dfers from the weekly statistics released on Wednesday by the National Records of Scotland, as the former covers patients who have tested positive and the latter involves all registered deaths where Covid- is mentioned on the death certicate, whether confirmed or suspected.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon:Labour leader highlights job losses across UKKeir Starmer highlighted job losses at Airbus, easyJet and others, adding in the Commons: #xCThere was nothing in the Prime Minister#xs speech for the . million people in hospitality or the . million in retail.#xCNext week#xs financial statement could be the last chance to save millions of jobs. Will the Prime Minister start now by extending the furlough scheme for those parts of the economy which are still most at risk #xD Boris Johnson said the best thing to do was helpthe economy to health by ensuring people are back in work and the virus is #xCdefeated and under control#xD, adding Labour could #xCstop equivocating, doing one thing one week and one thing another week#xD.Airbus is among the companies which has announced job losses :Keir Starmer says hes not blind to the riskSir Keir Starmer said the issue is a #xCconcern#xD as there is nationwide lting of lockdown restrictions this weekend #xCwithout an app, without clear data for local authorities or the world-beating system we were promised#xD.He added: #xCI support the easing of restrictions but unlike the Prime Minister, I#xm not blind to the risks and I don#xt think anybody  should be.#xDSir Keir said: #xCOf the , new cases of Covid infections per week in mid June, just , were reached and asked to provide details. So now three quarters of people with Covid- are not being reached. How does the Prime Minister explain that #xDSir Keir Starmer Boris Johnson replied: #xCAs he knows very well the test, track and trace operation is actually reaching huge numbers of people and causing them to self-isolate in ways I don#xt think he conceivably could have expected a month ago when this system was set up.Mr Johnson added that the Test and Trace system #xChas now reached , contacts, , contacts who have undertaken to self-isolate to stop the disease spreading#xD.:Flippant PM blasted over Bournemouth beaches incidentBoris Johnson was accused of #xCbatting away#xD legitimate concerns from seaside resorts.Sir Keir Starmer said: #xCThe Prime Minister can#xt just bat away challenge. These are matters of le and death, other people#xs livelihoods. #xCAn example of this, last week the Member for Hoveasked the Prime Minister how can seaside towns be expected to cope with likely influx of visitors to beaches and parks during the hot weather  #xCThe Prime Minister replied, show some guts. Two days later Bournemouth beach was closed with , visitors, a major incident was declared. #xCDoes the Prime Minister now regret being so flippant #xD Mr Johnson replied that he was making it #xCabsolutely clear that as we go forward with our plan, our cautious plan for opening up the economy, it is very, very important that people who do represent seaside communities, places where UK tourists will want to go, should be as welcoming as they can possibly be#xDThousands packed onto beaches in Bournemouth :New figures show where most cases are being foundPublic Health England has released a weekly snapshot of new Covid- cases in England, by local authority.The snapshot shows the rate of new cases in each area, based on tests that have been carried out in laboratoriesand in the wider community .As such it gives a more comprehensive overview of the country than the daily figures for local areas that are published on the Department of Health website, which are based only on pillar  testing.The latest Public Health England snapshot is for the week ending June , and shows four areas in the top category of  or more cases per , population:BarnsleyBradfordLeicesterRochdaleThere are six areas in the next category :BedfordBlackburn with DarwenKirkleesOldhamRotherhamTamesideA new snapshot for the week ending June  is due to be published on Thursday, as part of Public Health England#xs weekly coronavirus surveillance report.:PM hopes for biggest ever thank you day for NHSBoris Johnson said he hopes the nation will come together for the #xCbiggest ever thank you day#xD for the NHS on Sunday. He told Prime Minister#xs Questions: #xCIt will provide the perfect moment to thank not just our amazing NHS and care workers but also those key workers who have helped in the national effort in our fight against coronavirus and all those across the country who have gone the extra mile for their local communities in these challenging times. #xCI#xm sure we can agree across this House the NHS represents the very best of us and we will always be there to support it.#xD Sunday July  marks the nd anniversary of the NHS.The under-fire Prime Minister has been criticised by the Labour Party leader :Starmer voices alarm over track and trace shortcomingsThe Labour leader told the House of Commons he was alarmed that two thirds of people can#xt be contacted because a #xCworld beating#xD test and trace system isn#xt in place.He said: #xCI support the easing of restrictions, but unlike the Prime Minister I#xm not blind to the risks.#xD:Number of deaths falling in ScotlandA total of , people have died in Scotland with confirmed or suspected coronavirus, according to the National Records of Scotland .Between June  and June   deaths relating to Covid- were registered, down  on the previous week, marking the ninth weekly consecutive fall and the lowest weekly total since mid-March.This week is the first time since March - that the total number of deaths registered, at ,, was below the five-year weekly average, of ,.The NRS statistics are published weekly and account for all deaths registered in Scotland where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate.They dfer from the lab-confirmed coronavirus deaths announced daily by the Scottish Government as they include suspected or probable cases of Covid-.Police patrol in Edinburgh as shops reopen :PMQs underway as Labour accuses government of not sharing dataPMQs is now underway.Labour leader Keir Starmer is straight on the attack, saying data about infection levels have not been shared with local authorities.#xCThe Prime Minister can#xt just bat away people#xs concerns,#xD the opposition leader said.Labour leader Keir Starmer :How Alton Towers will look when it reopens to thrillseekers on SaturdayAlton Towers has given visitors an insight as to how the theme park will look when it reopens on Saturday.The popular tourist attraction will open its doors on July  for the first time in more than three months as lockdown measures ease in England.Pictures taken from inside the park show guests will have a completely dferent experience.Like zoos, anyone wanting to visit Alton Towers will have to pre-book for entry, with the park opening at limited capacity.For the full story, click here:One in eight care home residents havent been testedAround one in eight care home residents have not yet been tested for coronavirus, a survey of more than  care homes has found. The National Care Forum , which represents  of the UK#xs social care charities, surveyed members on the whole home-testing experience for staff and residents. Respondents said , staffand ,of residents in care homes are still awaiting Covid- tests. This is despite all homes with residents over  having been offered testing, and could be due to struggles to access tests and staff absences.Care staff are facing huge challenges in the wake of pandemic:US buys up virtually all stocks of anti-viral drug remdesivirThe Trump administration has bought up virtually all stocks for the next three months of a drug shown to work against Covid-.The US Department of Health and Human Servicessaid it had secured more than , treatment courses of remdesivir for American hospitals.This represents % of the US pharmaceutical firm Gilead#xs projected authorised therapeutic for Covid-.#xCTo the extent possible, we want to ensure that any American patient who needs remdesivir can get it.#xCThe Trump administration is doing everything in our power to learn more about le-saving therapeutics for Covid- and secure access to these options for the American people.#xDRead the full story here.Donald Trump :KEY EVENTTwo more places of concern after government adviser at the start of the pandemic, says it is only a matter of time until more places impose local lockdowns as Leicester has done following a spike of Covid- cases.And it is feared both Doncaster and Bradford could both see similar lockdowns following a worrying rise in the number of cases.For the full story, click hereExperts say more local lockdowns in England can be expected:Coronavirus-infected coughs can spray ft awayyou dont wear a face maskThe best face masks for stopping the spread of Covid- are well-fitting cone-style and home-made versions made from multiple fabric layers, according to a new study.Researchers analysed which were the best - and worst - face masks for minimising the spread of droplets from coughs or sneezes to mitigate the transmission of the virus.Tests showed that the least effective ieties were loosely-folded face masks and bandana-style coverings which provide minimal stopping-capability for respiratory droplets.The study, published in the journal Physics of Fluids, also discovered that coughs can potentially travel up to  feet, around . metres,unobstructed - much further than the new one-metre social distancing guideline.For the full story, click hereWith a folded cotton handkerchief, droplets traveled  foot,  inches:Turkey expects to welcome Brits again soonTurkey is hoping to welcome British tourists again shortly and expects to be on the list of destinations to be exempted from the UK#xs quarantine measures. story: NewsPub changes name due to slave trader connection - is now Pubby McDrunkface insteadA pub that was named after slave trader Edward Colston has been given a hilarious temporary new nameShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience WriterRobin Murray:,  JUL NewsThe pub has a temporary new name ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA pub in Bristol that was named after Edward Colston has a new temporary name - and itaposs rather amusing.This comes just weeks after Black Lives Matter protestors took down a statue of the th century slave trader in the city and dumped it in the harbour. The owners of the St Michaelaposs Hill pub are currently on the hunt for a new permanent name for the establishment, reports Bristol Live.Theyaposve invited the public to help choose the new name, but in the meantime have placed a banner over the door, proclaiming that it will temporarily be called Ye olde Pubby McDrunkface. Honestly, we donapost think we could come up with a better namewe tried. Paul Frost, the landlord of the pub, said: There hasnapost been a lot of chatter about our name since the statue came down, but I thought weaposd be inundated with suggestions. We thought weaposd give the pub a temporary name to kick off some discussion about it and get the ball rolling. The -year-old, who also runs The Langton in St Annes continued: The name we went for is a nod to Boaty McBoatface. I wanted to go simply with Pubby McPubface but my manager Josh suggested Ye olde Pubby McDrunkface, which is much better. The sign, which was designed by pub manager Josh Louis and printed by Vistaprint, was put up outside on June  and has garnered plenty of smiles from passers-by and people whoaposve spotted it on social media.  It says: The Clearly Temporarily Named Ye Olde Pubby McDrunkface. Suggestions welcome . Underneath the sign is a board that reads: We are listening. Black Lives Matter. Frost added that he will spend time listening to all name suggestions as he doesnapost want to rush this decision. Thereaposs been a good jovial response to the new name which is nice to see. Itaposs been taken in the spirit I hoped it would be.

title: an inspiration to everyone tributes to the late dundee dance teacher doreen winter
story: A Dundee dance teacher who taught generations of city youngsters over more than six decades has died only weeks after being diagnosed with a terminal illness.Dozens of tributes have been paid to Doreen Winter of Dundee#s Dorwin School of Dancing, who died last Friday, aged .Doreen, who would have been  on July , taught dancing in Dundee for  years and was teaching up until  a week before lockdown.Her daughter, Linda, travelled from her home in Perth, Australia, five weeks ago to be with her mum and said she would be very sorely missed.#This is the end of an era. My dear mother has been a Dundee icon for many, many years,# she said.#She meant so many things to so many dferent people, all positive.#Mum just kept on dancing for as long as she could.#She was teaching dance right up until a week before lockdown. She was a real trooper. I am so proud of her. She was a strong and very giving lady and everyone she taught loved her.#She was a great role model for everyone she taught and I never saw her bitter or angry.#Doreen was diagnosed with a terminal illness seven weeks ago and was told only four days later that there was no treatment available.Linda said: #I had to get special permission to come home to be with her and she was absolutely delighted when I made it. I was so worried I wouldn#t be able to get here. I#m so glad I got to be with her at the end.#She was delighted when on June  the girls from the Dundee Sparkletts twirling group managed to get along to see her through the window.#She had a dferent story for each of the girls, that#s just what she was like. She was so uncomplaining about everything.#I am a nurse back home in Australia and I can honestly say she was the easiest patient I have ever had.#Doreen grew up in Downfield, the daughter of Tom Donaldson, who ran a bakery in Haldane.She began competitive dancing at a very young age and started teaching when she was .Doreen#s first love had been Highland dancing, which took her all over the world including Russia, America, China, Turkey and Italy as well as to other European cities.Linda said: #She was heavily involved in cultural dance exchanges. She was also a dance examiner and travelled widely with that.#As well as Highland dance, Doreen taught twirling, tap, line dancing and majorettes, and more recently was involved with the Dundee Sparkletts troupe.Linda added: #Mum was a member of the Gay Gordon#s Dancers, Downfield Musical Society  and her highland dancers, back in the late #s and early #s, were used on some of the Alexander Brothers shows and Ronnie Coburn shows across Scotland.#She also sang across Scotland on some of these shows.#Doreen also worked for a time as a silver service waitress in Dundee and in H Samuel the jeweller.As well as Linda, Doreen had two sons, Keith and Alan, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren.A spokesman for Dundee Sparkletts said: #She was an inspiration to everyone she met.#The girls at Dundee Sparkletts loved going to her class each week learning lots of techniques while having fun.#Not only was she their teacher, she treated every one of the girls as her own, building their confidence, encouraging them even when times were challenging and getting them all to believe in themselves.#Doreen#s funeral, which is private because of Covid- restrictions, is to be held next week.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: dundee fc james mcpake jimmy nicholl josh meekings
story: Dundee manager James McPake admits he was gutted to lose assistant boss Jimmy Nicholl as part of cost-cutting measures at Dens Park.The experienced right-hand man and sports scientist Cammy McDermid were let go by the Dark Blues last week, with club captain Josh Meekings leaving on Monday after rejecting the reduced terms offered to him.Discussing the departure of his No, McPake hailed the contribution of former Man United, Rangers and Northern Ireland defender Nicholl and said he “loved” working with him.He said: “He has had a fantastic career in coaching and will be missed by everyone at Dens.“On a happy note, I was delighted to hear that he will be getting kept on at Northern Ireland.“I wish he was staying with us, too, but it’s not to be. He is a victim of this global pandemic.“It is a tough one for me and the players but it is even tougher for Jimmy and Cammy, who has also left the club.“It is an absolute gutter for the two of them. But no one could have predicted how this virus would affect clubs like ours.”The Dark Blues are all but certain to promote first-team coach Dave Mackay to take over as number two but no decision has been made yet.McPake made the point that he has other things on his mind right now.“I think it is too early to say what will happen,” said McPake.“Thatis not what’s in my head just now.“What I am thinking about is losing members of staff due to cost-cutting measures.”McPake yesterday confirmed he will not be involved in pay cut talks between the club and its players.The Dark Blues’ squad members have been asked to agree to salary reductions of around % and while Meekings said no and headed off to pastures new, experienced midfielder Paul McGowan has gone the other way and agreed to stay.McPake stressed it will be up to iniduals to do what is best for themselves and their families, and the pay discussions will be done at managing director level by John Nelms.He said: “I can confirm that there have been talks about deductions but that’s for iniduals and that’s way above me.“That’s something that I am not really involved in and, evenI were, it wouldn’t be fair for me to speak about as we are talking about people’s livelihoods and salaries.“Cuts have been offered but what each inidual’s cut is, that’s private between them and whoever is dealing with it at the club.“It will just be inidualised. Theymay come back to the club with dferent ideas, I don’t know.“They might all come back and say yes or they might say no. It is a tough one for me to predict and, as for a deadline, I genuinely don’t know.”Askedthe coaching staff had also been asked to take a pay cut, the Dens boss replied: “That’s not something I will go into.”As for Meekings, there were definitely no hard feelings towards the defender from his now former gaffer.McPake added: “Meeks is gone and that’s a shame because he did great for me as captain of this club.“He was offered a deal and it was his choice to say whether it was acceptable or not.“He chose to reject it but I wish him well for the future.“It is sad to see him go but I fully understand decisions that people make, particularly under the circumstances we are in with the pandemic.“I have no bad words to say about him at all.”On a brighter note, McPake was understandably upbeat regarding McGowan’s decision to say yes to his new terms.He said: “I am delighted that he committed himself to the club.“Gowser is a leader without even realising he is a leader.“He might moan a lot on the pitch at times but that is because he has high standards and he is often the one to express an opinion when he thinks the players are not hitting those high standards.“At times like these, you need people with character at your club and Gowser certainly has that.“He never shirks responsibility and that is why he has such real affinity with the Dundee fans.“I think the talks with him were over and done within a day or so. title: dundee fc supporters society john nelms donation funds
story: The Dundee FC Supporters’ Societyadmits it rejected an approach for a “no-strings-attached” donation from Dundee FC.But the fans’ group insists it wants to help the cash-strapped club through Covid- – and has called for “constructive dialogue” with managing director John Nelms.The Dark Blues hit out at the DFCSS after revealing the group refused a request to donate a five-figure sum from its cash reserves.Dee director Bob Hynd quit the Society board over the row, with the Dens Park club accusing the group of offering “little to no help” over a period of seven years, despite having profited from the club’s intellectual property.The DFCSS hit back at that claim, maintaining it has a duty to its members not to simply hand over cash.And, in a statement, the Society – which is working to set-up a monthly, direct-to-club donation scheme – revealed its willingness to sit down to discussions about alternative funding arrangements.“The DFCSS DeeLe directors wish to confirm their extreme surprise and disappointment at the resignation of Bob Hynd and record their gratitude for his valued contribution to the Society and the important role he performed as a colleague and bridge between the Society and the club over the years,” said the statement.“All Society directors and members are extremely passionate Dundee supporters and we want to help the club through these extraordinarily dficult times.“The recent press statement from the club refers to the Society rejecting a request for financial assistance from the funds we currently hold.“The fact of the matter is the Society rules, in common with other supporters’ trusts, do not encourage ‘no strings attached’ donations such as this and that is why the Society directors decided they could not agree to the request as it stood.“In light of the perilous situation facing clubs across the country the Society board is exploring other means by which it could provide the club with funding at this time, title: dundee united steve mcclaren fc twente wout brama
story: Steve McClaren transformed FC Twente into shock Dutch title winners during his spell in the Netherlands and he is the perfect choice to make Dundee United great again, according to current captain Wout Brama.The Tannadice club are close to replacing Robbie Neilson, who shocked fans by leaving for Hearts last month.McClaren remains the bookies’ favourite to take charge of the Premiership new boys, with SFA performance director Malky Mackay also in the running.Twente skipper Brama – now in his second spell at De Grolsch Veste – was a vital part of McClaren#s team who won the Ereisie for the first and only time in their history ten years ago.The Dutch international midfielder sees similarities between United and the Enschede outfit and says the Championship title winners would be making a huge statement of intentthey lured the former Man United No to Tayside.Brama, , said: #When Steve first came to Twente is was a big surprise to us because this was a guy who had been England manager and assistant to Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United.#To have a manager with his CV really took the club up to a dferent level.#I read that he was about to be appointed Dundee United manager and there are definitely similarities between Twente Enschede and Dundee United because both clubs are not regarded as one of the biggest in their countries.#We were not and we will never be the biggest club in Holland, so it was a huge challenge for Steve to come here.#But he arrived at a club who had been doing well because we had finished second in the league and that helped him too.#His job was to take us up to the highest level and he did that.#You have to remember, Steve was regarded as the best manager in England at one point and that#s why he got the national job.#Steve is a great guy, a fantastic manager and he has a good sense of humour too. He really liked the club and the region where the club are based. It was just a good fit between the club and Steve himself.#Our area in Holland is full of people who are down to earth and Steve loved that. He#d gone from the pressure of getting the sack from England and all the attention that carried with it, to a small region in the east of Holland which is very quiet and he relished that.#The club was well run and well organised. You can ask anyone in Enschede and they all have nothing but positive things to say about Steve.#Hopefully, it will be the same with him and Dundee United too.#Brama says McClaren wouldn’t go into Tannadice and make wholesale changes – and he raved about the former Middlesbrough manager#s man-management skills.He recalled: #Steve had two periods with us as manager and, of course, he won us the league for the first time in our history in his first time at the club.#Him being manager made it a very, very positive experience for me.#When he first came in, the important thing for him was not to change everything straight away. In the beginning, he didn#t change a lot of things, he just observed.#He also didn#t bring in his own coaches, he kept the very good Dutch coaches we had at the club. He had Erik ten Hag, who is now Ajax manager, at the club as a coach and Alfred Schreuder as his assistant manager, who went on to manage Hoffenheim in the Bundesliga.#So he used the coaches who were there and their knowledge and allowed the coaches here to do their job without interference and that certainly helped too.#He was a great manager for us. He was liked and respected by the players, coaches, everyone at the club in a very good way. He was the boss and everyone knew it.#For me as a player, he was fantastic. I was out of the team when Steve arrived because there were two new players who were in my position.#But he played me in a game against Arsenal in Europe when he needed a more defensive midfielder and I played just about every game since then.#He could trust me. I was only  at the time and I liked that he showed enough confidence in me as a young player to discuss tactics with me.#It was a very Dutch way to work and it was another example of how he adapted. He wanted to integrate with the Dutch way of playing, training and thinking and that#s what made him a big success.#Hopefully, he will be as big a success at Dundee United as he was at Twente.#LEE WILKIE: Malky Mackay#s past mistakes are well-documented#he deserves the chance to be Dundee United manager" title"#LEE WILKIE: Malky Mackay#s past mistakes are well-documented#he deserves the chance to be Dundee United manager# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-malky-mackay-dundee-united embed # secretlLVCwFjUQ" data-secret"lLVCwFjUQ" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
